items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely. The higher water levels will continue through today, Wednesday the 2nd of February, and the flood alert may need to stay in force for the next few days.  High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas.  We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update messages when necessary.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Thursday the 3rd of February.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely. The higher water levels will continue through today Wednesday the 2nd of February, and the flood alert may need to stay in force for the next few days.  High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry road in Horning.   We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update messages when necessary.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Thursday the 3rd of February.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely. The higher water levels will continue through today, Wednesday 2 February, and the flood alert may need to stay in force for the next few days.  High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay.  We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update messages when necessary.  We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Thursday 3 February.

This Flood Alert has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely this afternoon on 03/02/2022 between 11:00 AM and 01:00 PM. The areas most at risk are around Canal Foot, where over-topping is expected, and Storth Sandside. Impacts are also possible at low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale. We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days which may result in flood warnings being issued over the weekend. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message: As a result of high spring tides and strong winds, tides will be at their highest this afternoon at 12:44 PM on 03/02/2022. Areas most at risk include Tiger's Tail, Wyre Dock, Burrow's Marsh, Burn Naze, Thornton, Trunnah, Stannah, Poulton-le-Fylde, Skippool, Hambleton, Cold Row, Little Singleton, Little Eccleston and Crow Woods. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected two hours before and after the high tide. We are within a cycle of high tides and as such we may issue further alerts over the coming days. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated by 05:00 PM on 03/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

Tides are expected to be higher than usual due to the forecast weather conditions during coming high tides.
Flooding is possible at low lying land and roads at Fiddlers Ferry between 01:15 PM and 01:45 PM, Eastford Road between 01:30 PM and 02:00 PM and Arpley Bridge between 01:45 PM and 02:15 PM on 03/02/2022. It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge.
We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next 3 days and as a result we may issue further alerts. The high tide on Thursday evening 03/02/2022 is not expected to reach flood alert.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 09:00 AM on 04/02/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Coast from St Bees Head to Millom
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:00 AM and 01:00 PM on Thursday the 03/02/2022. Braystones Beach is likely to be most affected with some over-topping expected. Other areas at risk include Low lying areas along the coast from St Bees Head to Millom including Ravenglass and Annaside.
We are expecting higher than normal tides over the next few days and as a result we may issue further alerts. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Stay away from beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated tomorrow morning or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
There is a possibility that this Flood Alert may be reissued for the Thursday, 03/02/2022, evening high tide and the Friday, 04/02/2022, morning high tide. 
We continue to monitor the situation.
